properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall likely Sunday and Sunday night. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into Eastern Ontario Sunday and persist until Monday morning. Precipitation may begin as snow before changing to rain in some areas. Total rainfall amounts of 20 to 40 mm are possible. The ground is still at least partially frozen over much of Eastern Ontario. As a result, it will have a limited ability to absorb this rainfall. Localized ponding in low-lying areas and on roads is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T18:01:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T10:02:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0742304062.2019
Area: Gatineau, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Tamworth - Sydenham - South Frontenac, Stirling - Tweed - Madoc, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park, Merrickville-Wolford - Kemptville, Westport - Charleston Lake, Brockville - Prescott, Gananoque - Mallorytown, Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Morrisburg - Long Sault, Prescott and Russell, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Plevna - Sharbot Lake - Western Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orl√©ans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe

properties.Title: Update: Flood Warning Continued For The Red River From Emerson To The Red River Floodway Channel Inlet
properties.Summary:
Description: Update: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure's Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a Flood Warning on the Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet due to high water flows. If you are in the affected area, be watchful of local waterways as flooding is likely to occur. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions given by local authorities. Listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Up-to-date information is available at www.gov.mb.ca/flooding and www.manitoba511.ca or stay tuned to local media.
Expires: 2019-04-13T11:15:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2019-04-12T11:22:35-05:00, 0F3373D4-C160-7AAB-B9CE-BFBB27598754
Area: Red River from Emerson to the Red River Floodway channel inlet
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A wintry mix of precipitation expected Sunday night through Tuesday. A low pressure system is expected to approach the province from the southwest on Sunday, and pass near southern New Brunswick on Monday before moving into the Gulf of St. Lawrence on Tuesday. Over northern New Brunswick, precipitation is expected to begin as a mix of snow and ice pellets on Sunday night. A transition through freezing rain to rain is then expected on Monday morning. Rain is likely to persist through the day on Monday before a changeover back to snow as the low pressure system pulls away on Monday night. Over southern New Brunswick, this system is currently expected to bring predominately rain, beginning on Sunday night. A brief changeover to snow is possible on Monday night as the low moves away. Precipitation will taper off over all areas through the day on Tuesday. At this time, it is too early to predict precipitation amounts associated with this system. Environment Canada meteorologists will monitor the system and provide more detail as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T15:46:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T07:47:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3361576565.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Grand Manan and Coastal Charlotte County, Woodstock and Carleton County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Kent County, Moncton and Southeast New Brunswick, Kouchibouguac National Park, Fundy National Park, Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Late season snowfall possible Sunday and Sunday night. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into portions of Southern Ontario Sunday morning or afternoon. With temperatures near the freezing mark, a messy mix of snow, ice pellets and freezing rain are possible. Some areas may also change to rain if temperatures rise above the freezing mark. Since the temperatures will be close to the freezing mark, there is a high degree of uncertainty regarding potential snowfall amounts. At this point, it appears that some areas may see snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm by Monday morning. However, for areas where precipitation changes to rain, amounts may be significantly less. Motorists are advised to prepare for potentially hazardous travel conditions Sunday and Sunday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T17:38:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T09:39:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0384293468.2019
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Deep River - Whitney - Eastern Algonquin Park, Western Algonquin Park - Lake of Two Rivers, Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County, Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County, Bancroft - Hastings Highlands - Denbigh, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Saugeen Shores - Kincardine - Southern Bruce County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major spring storm will hit the province of Quebec on Monday and Tuesday. Generally 15 to 25 centimetres of heavy snow is expected, but accumulations could be even greater over higher elevations of the Gaspe Peninsula and parts of the Lower North Shore. Snow may change to rain at times. Precipitation will begin early Monday and continue until late in the day on Tuesday. Precipitation will be accompanied by strong northeasterly winds. Accumulation of wet, heavy snow could result in broken tree limbs. A low pressure system from Texas will intensify as it tracks across New England and the Maritimes on Monday. It will persist over the Gulf of St Lawrence on Tuesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T16:20:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T08:21:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1300318853.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Spring snow expected for many southern mountain passes on Saturday. A Pacific frontal system will move across southern BC on Saturday. Snow will develop over the highway passes beginning early in the morning. Initially, snow levels will be near 800 metres and gradually rise to 1200 metres that afternoon. Near the Coquihalla summit and the Kootenay Pass, 10 to 15 cm of snow can be expected by Saturday afternoon. Additional amounts of 5 to 10 cm are possible Saturday night as convective flurries develop in the wake of the front. Snowfall over other southern BC highway passes will be less intense and total amounts nearer 5 cm can be expected on Saturday. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T15:54:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T07:55:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2063034254.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Active weather for Newfoundland next week. Meteorologists are monitoring a developing weather system that appears set to affect the Island for the first half of next week. While it is too soon to provide specific details, indications point toward a prolonged event with strong winds and a variety of precipitation types. Precipitation will likely arrive over southwestern Newfoundland on Monday morning and spread across the Island during the day. It appears most areas will receive snow on the leading edge of the system before a transition through freezing rain to rain. Over northern Newfoundland, however, precipitation may remain as mainly snow. Some temporary improvement can be expected during the day on Tuesday, but colder air will follow from west to east Tuesday night into Wednesday, changing precipitation back to snow, with potential for accumulation. Strong easterly winds will develop over most areas on Monday and continue through Monday night before easing on Tuesday. Gusty northerly winds will then likely follow for Tuesday night into Wednesday. The northerlies should subside Wednesday night as the system finally pulls away. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-13T15:53:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T07:54:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2157236837.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Bay St. George, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay, Terra Nova, Northern Peninsula East, Parson's Pond - Hawke's Bay, Port Saunders and the Straits

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major spring storm will hit the province of Quebec from Sunday evening into Monday. Rainfall amounts of 30 to 40 millimetres are expected south of and along the St Lawrence Valley between Montreal and Quebec City as well as over the Ottawa Valley. For a number of regions to the north and east, however, 15 to 25 centimetres of heavy snow is expected. Heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. Flooding is possible in low lying areas. Accumulation of wet, heavy snow could result in broken tree limbs. A low pressure system from Texas will intensify as it tracks across New England and the Maritimes on Monday. Precipitation generated by this system will reach Southern Quebec beginning Sunday evening and intensify overnight while spreading eastward. Conditions will gradually improve late in the day on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T16:18:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T08:19:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1125504865.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain likely Sunday. Precipitation associated with an approaching low pressure system is expected to move into portions of Southern Ontario Sunday morning. For higher terrain areas, several hours of freezing rain are possible as temperatures are expected to remain near the freezing mark. Untreated surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T17:24:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-13T09:25:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1367926783.2019
Area: Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Mount Forest - Arthur - Northern Wellington County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County, Caledon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong easterly winds continue to cause blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Winds are forecast reintensify this evening and will likely remain strong through to at least Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-13T14:59:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-12T23:00:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0808797394.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Rain or freezing rain will taper off near noon today. Along the coast, freezing rain is likely to persist for several hours as temperatures hover near zero this morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
